All Games > Early Access Games > StarMade
Community Hub
StarMade
StarMade is a voxel-based 3D sandbox space shooter. Play in your own universe or on a multiplayer server. Participate in epic fleet battles, strive to dominate entire galaxies and harness the universe’s resources for your industrious empire or the destruction of others. The universe is yours!
User reviews: Mostly Positive (1,443 reviews) - 74% of the 1,443 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Nov 27, 2014

Title: StarMade
Genre: Action , Adventure , Indie , RPG , Simulation , Strategy , Early Access
Developer: Schine, GmbH
Publisher: Schine, GmbH
Release Date: Nov 27, 2014

Visit the website View the manual View stats View update history Read related news View discussions Find Community Groups
Share Embed  

Early Access Game

Get instant access and start playing; get involved with this game as it develops.

Note: This Early Access game is not complete and may or may not change further. If you are not excited to play this game in its current state, then you should wait to see if the game progresses further in development. Learn more

What the developers have to say:

Why Early Access?

“ We are offering the full current version of the game to play for free in alpha, scroll down!

We are using early access to give the players the possibility to play this game, as well as giving them the opportunity to be a contributing factor in the game's development. We are a small independent company, and this will help us to develop the game further (however, we are not reliant on steam). The game will still be free to try out from our own webpage, as well as a free version available here.

All existing customers that have an upgraded account can trade that status for a steam key, and then use their steam ID to upgrade their account again. ”

Approximately how long will this game be in Early Access?

“Depending on the development, this game will get a lot more features, as its core allows for a lot of possibilities to make the game a more enjoyable experience. It will stay in Early Access until most of the known bugs are fixed, and we feel confident in the game's overall systems.”

How is the full version planned to differ from the Early Access version?

“We have many features planned for development, we couldn't honestly list them all. You can check out what we're working on, or what we will be working on at our website or the official community forums. A couple of the many features we have lined up are mission systems (quests), GUI overhaul and ship-wide hp. Game performance and scalability is our underlining priority.”

What is the current state of the Early Access version?

“We have had stable versions of the game and server for over a year now. The game has just reached critical milestones in its design.”

Will the game be priced differently during and after Early Access?

“The game's price will slowly rise during the early access period as features are progressively added. This system will favour those who have purchased and showed their support in the early stages of the game.”

How are you planning on involving the Community in your development process?

“We already extensively involve the community in the development of the game. Pre-steam release we were roughly at 300,000 people registered on our account system, requests/bug reports/suggestions are constantly read by our team. Many player contributed suggestions have already been implemented into the game. We as a team, are heavily involved with the community.”

Recent updates View all (21)

November 2

StarMade v0.19476 Transporters, Activation Gates, Optimizations and more

Hello players,

The Schine Team has been hard at work since TwitchCon, and we are super excited to finally be able to show you what we’ve been working on!

Side Note: We will be jumping back into our planned 2 week release cycle schedule, with our next release scheduled for November 6th.


Transporters

A long awaited feature is finally here! Transporters! Transporters allow you to instantly warp between transporter platforms within a short distance (the current sector, and any adjacent sectors). Be careful though! Using a transporter between ships will temporarily bring down shields on both the sending and receiving ships. If shields drop from transporters, they will recharge back up at the ship’s set shield recharge speed.

Much like other systems within StarMade, the transporter system comes with a transporter computer and transporter modules. The modules are simply pads that you stand on, while the computer is used to control and activate the module. Make sure that you can either reach the computer while standing on the module, or have someone manage your transporter room. Logic will be added to the system in a coming update.

Destination setting can be done from within the computer. All available destinations will become available. Any transporters that are located within the current ship or any of its docks will be available as a destination. Any transporters that are on other entities located either in the current sector or adjacent sectors, can also be made available by setting them to “public/faction access”. Be aware though that upon warping to a transporter on another entity, the shields of both entities will be dropped and have to be recharged! So never leave your transporters open; or you might find your shields dropped or a boarding party invading your vessel.


Transporter Beacon

The transporter beacon is a personal tool that enables the user to warp to a transporter as long as the vessel is in vicinity. Just use its beam to mark the transporter controller you want to be warped to, then open your inventory, right click on the item, and hit ‘transport’ to be warped to that transporter. This is very handy for exploration without a proper way to get back. In a future update there will also be a ship beam that lets the player set a manual target for a transporter.


Activation Gates

Activation Gates work just like Warp Gates with the difference being that instead of warping, they will emit a ‘true’ signal when a ship is passing through. This is only activated on actual passing of an entity. This feature will help for logic with much bigger structures where the trigger area blocks start to lag.


Race Gates

This is a feature I wanted to do for some time. It seems a bit random but is part of a bigger picture. There are most likely several bugs with the race gates, however they should be mostly functional for basic racing.

To create a race track, you will have to create a chain of Gates. These gates can be on the same or multiple entities. To link gates, the same method as the warp gates is used: the marker beam. Right click with the marker beam on the computer of one destination gate and left click on the gate you want to create the link from. Continue to do this process for each Gate in the chain, linking the Race Gate Computer to the next gate’s computer.

Then you can create a race by activating the Race computer with ‘R’. The computer you use is going to be the starting gate of that race. Players can join either from the computer itself (if it’s public access), or from the menu on the top (messages/quests) if you have any dialog open.

To start the race, you have to link from an activation module/button to the race computer you used to create the race (the starting gate). The race will start when a true signal is received in that race computer, so it’s possible for the builder to set up logic count downs and other mechanics that all racers can see.

The race creator can even set laps and buy-in money which is then paid out to the first 3 finishers. We will keep an eye on how this works in the real world and tweak the settings if needed in a future update.


Raycasting Optimizations, aka a lot less lag from extensive mining

Planet eating miners that in the past brought down a server in seconds now only create a fraction of the lag they did before.


Database update to get rid of block data for found stations

Databases now load the NPC stations without copying them to the database as long as they are not modified. This means a huge decrease of database growth.

Admins can retroactively apply the feature to their db (as it only is applied to newly spawned stations) with the startup parameter:

-cleanuptransient

PLEASE NOTE: Depending on size, this can take hours (we are talking 48h+ for 200gb. This will most likely be optimized with the next update), as the program looks through every file looking for similarities and header matches.

Also PLEASE BE SURE TO CREATE A BACKUP before doing this.


Asteroid replenish server option


There is now an option to periodically let the server replenish asteroids in the server cfg. To trigger, a sector will have to be unloaded and completely empty. If the time of the time it last replenish is beyond the waiting period set in the config, the sector will regenerate. This will help bridge the time until a better system takes its place.


Bug Fixes

One bug that had haunted me for a long time is (hopefully) finally fixed. Players should no longer fall out of moving ships upon sector change.

A full list of bug fixes can be found in our news section here .


Next update

As noted above we’ll be returning to our planned 2-week release schedule. This will help make development a lot more predictable for the community and especially servers. To get us back on schedule our next release will be later this week and will be addressing a lot of bug fixes and performance optimizations that come out of this release.


Thank you for playing StarMade,

- The Schine Team.

9 comments Read more

September 7

StarMade v0.19431 - No more turret lag, Jump Inhibitors & Admin Tools

Hello players,

This update is meant to clean up some stuff that has been in the queue for a while. It is also an update for server admins to make their lives a little bit easier.

YouTube™ Video: Starmade Update 0.19431 | Jump Inhibitors 
Views: 9,372
This video features an outline of the latest stable build, patch 0.19431. This features new Jump Inhibitor blocks. With them you can prevent players from jumping away.



Turret/Raildock Optimization
Due to optimizations in several parts of the code to reduce the quantity of collision checks and make them faster altogether, as well as some relief in the docking chain updates, approximately 90% of turret lag has been eliminated. Depending on turret sizes and count, ships that before had a hard time to get 5fps with active AI now run smoothly with almost no lag due to turrets.

Also, some advanced algorithms have been implemented to reduce lag on very large turrets, once again making use of special properties in a block game. If anyone is interested in the techniques used, please leave a comment and I’ll write up a dev blog for it.


Jump Inhibitors
In pvp, the advantage of being able to change multiple one-block jump drives to jump into an enemy sector, fire all weapons, and jump out has been rightfully criticized a lot.

To combat this situation, but not to nerf long distance traveling, a new system has been introduced: The jump inhibitor.



This system works exactly like the jump drive with the difference that a player doesn’t have to actively charge it. It can be turned on/off at will. When on, the jump inhibitor will discharge all jump drives in the same or adjacent sectors. The rate of discharge depends on the amount of modules used on the jump inhibitor. This means if you have a strong enough jump drive, you can still overcome the jump inhibitor.


Inventory Management

Better creative mode inventory
The creative mode inventory has been improved to now copy & paste items to the hotbar instead of moving them. Also, the search will no longer blend out filtered items, but display them one after another.


Inventory Pulling add-ons
You can now set an inventory to pull whole categories (same as in a shop). This should make automated inventory management a lot easier.

You can now also pull meta items.


Admin Tools

Server Update Lag Monitoring Tool
A tool to monitor sectors and objects that take very long to update has been added. This will make it easy to identify any sector where a lot of slowdown is happening. You can turn on the monitor in the general options ingame, but you have to be admin to enter the detailed view (F7). Lag will also be recorded so you can check on lag-spikes after they happened. Be aware that the reason, the “server not responding” message can appear is not only due to objects taking long to update on the server. It could be a simple network lag, too.

Restrictions for the Game Config


Admins can now add restrictions to the GameConfig.xml to better control their server and prevent possible abuse/lag.

There are examples for possible restrictions in /data/config/GameConfigDefault.xml (if you already have an existing GameConfig.xml in your install dir, you have to edit that, as the default is only a template that gets copied if no config exists)


  • Restrict ships by mass or block-count
  • Restrict ship computers by count per type
  • Restrict ship systems by connected groups per computer (prevents monster salvagers)

Starmote has been revived
The tool now once again works, but is still a little barebone. A lot more features will be added in the future though.


Temporary Bans/Whitelisting
Admins can now issue temporary bans. Players will be notified about the time remaining on their ban on attempting to connect to that server.

The option has been added to the standard ban commands like for example

"/ban (playername) (kick) [reason] [time]"


Wave management
Admins can now manually manage spawnable waves. This will be applied to all the spawning AI on the server.

Each wave can be assigned a difficulty (should be between 1 and 10 for now), and even a faction.

Upon the game requiring a wave it will use the closest difficulty of a wave with the faction it needs to spawn on.

Wave Management can be accessed in the admin tab of the catalog.



If no wave is set for a faction, and the AI requests one for it, the old system of enemy usable flags will be used.


Texture updates

As some of you may have noticed, we are in the midst of working on new texture features.
In the coming weeks, emissive, specular and shine maps will be added to the game. The project is ongoing and still in infancy, should you spot any anomalies please report your findings to Kupu. He has an open thread for such things in the Texture Pack sub-forum.


http://starmadedock.net/threads/kupus-thread.839/


#IMPORTANT#

As we found that the quality suffers too much from compression to the point where the next lower resolution looks almost better than a compressed higher one, Texture compression has been disabled as a default setting from now on. If you are experiencing extreme FPS drop, we recommend you either reduce the resolution of your texture pack, turn off normal maps, or re-enable Texture Compression in the Advanced Options within the Starmade launcher.

Emissive and Specular maps will soon be available in the Pixel pack for those running on slower systems.


Fixes
T580 Nullpointer while saving of Station blueprints from multiplayer to local
T576 Amount sellable appended instead of replace when overselling using sell amount
T551 Turrets are not saved and linked correctly in shipyards
T546 Using "create docking" on station causes nullpointer

T510 undocking ship from shipyard will not allow you to redock it
T501 Cooldown/reload animation not intuitive
T490 Planet part entities does not vanish even without any blocks
T489 ship catalog manager does not sort anymore
T467 Highlighting/selecting sectors on galaxy map
T463 placing block on asteroid not previously built on drops asteroids&#39; original mass to 0
T450 Fix for entity-flag exploit does not affect already created entities.
T436 Factories on asteroids
T428 Stay attached to ship while being logged out
T415 Unable to kick members out of faction
T233 Chat kick and ban options
T225 radar jammer pirate exploit
T99 Structure Tab: UNABLE TO LOAD GUI-UNIT: Jamming System


Thanks for playing StarMade,

- schema and the Schine Team

Report bugs and leave feedback for this game on the discussion boards

Try out the full game for free in Alpha!

We are currently offering the full version of the game for free on our demo. This will be throughout Alpha, as we believe a user wanting to purchase a game that is in open alpha, should get to try out and test the current full state of the game first. We also need as many testers as possible, your reports, feedback and input is invaluable!

So... why should you purchase the game if it's currently free?

  • Support the developers!
  • You'll still have access to the latest version of the game when the demo stops being supported/updated. (Access to the full version when released)
  • Get it cheaper! As more features are added, the price will progressively increase. This will benefit those who supported the game earlier.
  • We're adding upgraded only features to our Registry system, this will not directly affect any game features, however it will give more access online. For example, blueprint hosting and multiple skin uploads for selection.

    What are you waiting for? Click that demo button, and try out the full game for free!

READ MORE

About This Game

A voxel-based 3D sandbox, set in the never-ending darkness of space. Create your own ships, explore new galaxies, stars and planets. Discover and salvage space stations, fight against pirates or opposing factions in multiplayer. Equip your ships with completely customisable weapons and conquer the galaxy. Trade and make a fortune, mass produce materials in gigantic factories. Design your very own space station. Create warp gates and network the universe at your front door.

The universe is a vast, mystical, beautiful, awe-inspiring place.... the universe is yours.

Built for scale to facilitate huge fully interactive objects, almost anything is possible. Various gameplay elements have been skillfully constructed to bring the ultimate sandbox space experience.

Dive into your own unique universe, and choose your path.

Key Features:

  • Massive procedurally generated sandbox universes
  • Developed for scalability
  • Multiplayer (dedicated servers)
  • Platform independent (Windows, Linux, Mac)
READ MORE

System Requirements

Windows
Mac OS X
    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP
    • Memory: 2 GB RAM
    • Graphics: OpenGL 2.1 Capable Graphics Card
    • Network: Broadband Internet connection
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: The game is made with speed and scalability in mind, so it runs on older machines. Java is required.
    Recommended:
    • OS: Windows 7
    • Memory: 4 GB RAM
    • Graphics: Nvidia Geforce, ATI
    • Network: Broadband Internet connection
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Java is required.
    Minimum:
    • OS: OS X Mountain Lion
    • Processor: 2 Ghz Intel Core2Duo
    • Memory: 2 GB RAM
    • Network: Broadband Internet connection
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Java is required.
    Recommended:
    • OS: OS X Mavericks 10.9.5 +
    • Processor: 2.4 Ghz Intel Core2Duo +
    • Memory: 4 GB RAM
    • Network: Broadband Internet connection
    • Hard Drive: 2 GB available space
    • Additional Notes: Java is required.

lukwan

479.3 hrs on record
Posted: October 14
Early Access Review
I started off loving Starmade...then we broke up. Now I spend time thinking about maybe giving it a another shot. I got into the game just after the big graphical re-boot having played Minecraft for years and checking out every voxel based, procedurally generated game I could find. I trolled Greenlight and found many wanna be contenders but Starmade impressed me with it's vision of what it wants to be. Like any relationship we fall in love with what could be, an ideal, sometimes a projection we place onto the other. I am love with what Starmade is trying to be, but has not yet become.

I lost interest for awhile when the docking update changed how turrets and ships dock. I was having a blast using the quirky old system to make a wide range of ships. The new system looks great and will solve many foibles and allow for a great variety of new designs. Just like with the Minecraft updates I got to enjoy a new game play each time Notch added something. Starmade is developing much the same way but because of it's own ambition each major update is quite disruptive. I have seen other early access wallow aimlessly, become abandoned or run off the rails in development. Starmade is doing none of these things. The danger, as I see it, is that Starmade may have trouble fulfilling it's grand ambitions.

Yes this game has a learning curve and I had fun riding that curve. This is the gold-standard for a complex game. If the learning is fun; success, if it is tedious; go play a game more suited to your short attention-span. A simple game is easy to learn and may become boring. A game with depth and possibilities is going take time to master but will remain engaging.

In it's current state (shipyards just released) Starmade is a very solid, playable early access game. There is a smattering of enemies to keep you improving your ship designs. There is no story arc yet but the ship-building is very polished. The Devs have build a proper foundation for an amazing game. It remains to be seen if they can build an engaging experience onto their ground-breaking mechanics while maintining balance.

Look elsewhere for the hate, I'm going to tell you what I love.

>Design matters. Where you put modules and how you protect your ship will really make a difference. Lots of room for tactics, countermeasures and cool systems. My first death in the game was a suicide. I designed anti-personnel pulsers in the airlock. Two passes and you are still ok, the third pass: you're dead. (You can come in, look around and leave safely or... linger and die.) I died testing the system and laughed my ♥♥♥ off.

>If you can dream it up you can build it. The first major ship I built was a salvage craft. I designed it to rescue shipwrecks. It was big and turned like a pig but fast and survivable. (I used it for daring rescue of a huge ship that got cored by pirates. It was an epic mission that left massive chucks missing from the old Flat-top but both vessels made it home intact. WooHoo)

I have designed the Tholian Enervater: a spider-themed hunter-killer. By design this craft can pursue a small fighter, slow it down using (web) multiple tractor beams (locking it in the crosshairs), rob it of power using (venom) an electro-mcGuffin ray and finally kill it. The theme of the spider worked both visually and tactically. Very Cool, good job Devs.

I decided to make a Whale-ship that could swallow a pirate-craft whole and then eat it. It worked just as I had hoped. (Unfortunately collisions are unavoidable)

I have stealth designs, a 'Tuttle-craft' for repairs, a surveyer/scout, a carrier/salvager, a mining ship with a huge beam. = ] Racing has just been introduced so now 'Tuning' will be a part of designing an efficient racer.

> Hey, it's fun to fly too. Never mind the awesome build mode with simple and powerful mirroring to reduce keystrokes... this is a very good space cockpit interface. Starmade features a huge number of elements introduced by previous space games but incorporates them well, often getting better results than its predecessors. It may not have the graphical grandeur of Klingon Academy but the systems controls are simple and easy to use in combat. After narrowly escaping from battle and badly damaged, I was able to reconfigure my systems and piece two non-functional weapons into one cobbled together mess of a gun. As I limped home I felt like Scotty, under an instrument panel with sparks flying, griping to the ham fisted captain who got us into this mess in the first place (oh, wait...that's me). Dog fighting is still a bit slow and not very dynamic with the current AI. I hope for more variation in their tactics besides "Send more guys".

>Potential. There's that dirty word again. With human crews for opponents in a more populated (by NPCs) world this game could be epic on a level beyond the average tired space-shooter game. It already has nailed the galactic map, shop-economy, building, flight control, and optimization. Read the developer's blog (Bench) to get a look at what is to come. The game updates every couple of weeks with new features, bug fixes and optimizations.

For the earth bound crowd who complain that game is broken: try to find it in your imagination that this game is still in the chrysalis phase. The grub's body is utterly dissolved in the cocoon before it can be reborn into a butterfly.

Early access is just that... if you don't get that stop bothering the developers and go play something with Zombies.

For the Developers: Schine on.
Read More

1,001.3 hrs on record
Posted: October 17
Early Access Review
TL;DR at the end.

So I have been playing Starmade for quite some time, clearly. With this review I will attempt to tell yall why I have nearly 1000hrs in this game.

I love it. I hate it. Never have I come across a game that can enrage me as much as this yet I still play it. I could not tell you how many times I stopped myself from punching my screen and snapping my keyboard in half just because I knew that if I did, I would not be able to play anymore.

Minecraft never got my attention any more than "oh, that looks neat". The idea of building a house and then what? Oooooo I have a house or a village or a Grand Castle! Good for you! Now what does it do? What do you do with it? That does not capture my intrest. You know what does? I can build a Grand Castle, pack it full of power generators, shields, engines and 'frikkin laser beams to go blow up anything I come across in the Galaxy.

Not all is fun and games in the 'verse though. There are issues. Glitches and bugs and bad coding, Oh My! Sometimes your turrets will teleport themselves halfway across the sector. Sometimes your ship wont fully load and it looks like you are missing half of it. Weapons 99% of the time work great, 1% of the time, they work about as good as a screen door on an airlock.

Yes, the Devs are very active. They do listen to the players. Updates rather often. Unfortunatly, the updates do kinda break the game sometimes. But, they get patched, things are a little wonky for a few days, then its back. All is good.

I couldnt tell you how many new people Ive seen pop in on a server and start screaming "sum 1 halp me! I haz the dumb n dnt knw what 2 do!!!!!" And when nobody responds because we are all too buisy with our brain cells commiting seppuku, they get butt hurt and leave without ever playing the game. Look, play the Tutorial, watch YouTube vids, get yourself into a good Faction. For the love of (insert desired religious icon here) dont type in general chat with "L337 speak" or "Millennial texting shorthand"! Take your time, learn the game, I can almost promise you that you will enjoy it.

TL;DR----
You like Space Engineers? Good for you, this is better.
You like Minecraft? You need to upgrade.
You like Eve? Cool, so did I. Get this instead.

Posted: October 28
Early Access Review
The most accessible space building game yet.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the theme of space. I've spent a few hours on this game with a friend of mine, she and I trecked through space in what could only be described as a "Miner's Life". Due to the game being far from complete, it is without question that methods of income are highly limited. The game begins you off with only a few blocks, the essentials for a hopeful star-merchant or space-hero, the basic thrusters, some cannons, a core for your ship, power supply blocks and some armors. Being a new-found space explorer, it is without question that chasing down pirates it THE stupidest thing you can attempt. ( Although it may be possible to successfully bring down a pirate at the start. )

Each system is a bit complex but it doesn't mean they are impossible for beginners to learn.

Power System suggestion: DO NOT CLUMP YOUR POWER SUPPLIES! It's ineffective.

The way the power supply works, I found it highly effective to line your system up in two 1 x X (X being any number you can afford ) lines that are spaced by one block each. So your systems would look like this:

-------------------------
------------------------- Each dash being power blocks.

I'm not adept enough to figure out how the weapons systems work but from my research they're highly ineffective when clumped. I've seen a lot of suggestions stating that thirty cannon block separate and independent of each other are far more effective than all of them combined. Making bigger cannons practically useless.

Also included in this game is a crafting system which I have not personally tested, it allows for the mined raw materials to be crafted into processed variants.

Also worth noting: Each star CAN be approached. It's a matter of designing a ship that won't be obliterated by the time you reach it. Planets can be approached as well and even be built on to house a base or landing dock for the miners and would-be pirates.

There are still a lot of systems that are implemented that I haven't even touched. A lot being complex or lacking an updated guide. For example: Turret systems, boarding systems, in depth power supplies, and as I've said before, weapons sytems.

It is a game worth checking out and I highly suggest trying it with a friend.

Posted: October 7
Early Access Review
This is a wonderful game with great potential.

The systems that are present are complex enough, and with the latest updates of jump drives, rails, and shipyards, it's pretty much a space ship enthusiast's dream come true. There are plenty of customization options. The weapons system is probably one of the most interesting that I have seen as well as the power systems.

The best part is that everything is MASSIVE. There is no end to it. There are pirates with suitable rewards for pve, entire planets to mine away, stars that will burn you if you get too close and traders who will sell just about anything. There is a strange mix of realism with fake rules that works really well with one another.

The building system is easy to pick up, with more depth the deeper you go. The crafting systems could use some work, but the anaysis of systems is beautifully done. With regular updates and great support, I can see this game going VERY far.

Also, do not call this Minecraft in space. The two games are similar on the surface, But they are in no ways alike.

Posted: October 16
Early Access Review
[written after the shipyard update] Starmade is a great game in my opinion. It is only in early access and seems like a full game! (not that they are done developing- keep adding! but it seems like its not in beta) It isn't really comparable to most games like minecraft or terraria because of the concept of space and ships, so really it depends on what you like- so if you like sandbox space shooter games, this is probably the best one out there. They really did a great job on the graphics and especially on explosions- the explosion has to get through blocks in front to damage blocks or players behind the blocks to show that the developers are serious about this. There is a wide variety of weapons to use and mix to fight pirates which can get boring based off of what I've heard once you get so far but it has a minecraft aspect- you can basically create any spaceship you can think of! I love the colorful hulls and the alien-ish block to make ships and stations look fancy. Also the machanics of the turrets on turrets and rails and shipyards and everything! You can make your space shooter dreams- in 3D! They do have a creative mode for any of you reading this review because it was just added and not many people know. The launcher may still look bad and it may not be very complete, but already I think this will lead to a perfect game. Wana see? Just go try the free demo! 9/10, would buy to support again
